docs.lead_paragraph: People with diabetes and high blood pressure risk not only dying early but tend to start losing mental abilities in middle age, researchers said today. The researchers, in findings published in the journal Neurology, said that it was important to start treating the two conditions, which are common in the United States and in other developed countries, as early as possible.

headline.main: Diabetes, Hypertension and Slower Wits, Too

docs.abstract: Mayo Clinic researchers find people with diabetes and high blood pressure tend to start losing mental abilities in middle age; Dr David Knopman, who led study, cites importance of early treatment (M)
docs.snippet: People with diabetes and high blood pressure risk not only dying early but tend to start losing mental abilities in middle age, researchers said today.    The researchers, in findings published in the journal Neurology, said  that it was important to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many diabetics may be going untreated simply because they were tested for the disease at the wrong time of day. A recent study suggests that if patients suspected of having diabetes are given blood tests in the afternoon, instead of the morning, their conditions may be overlooked. That is because plasma glucose levels, used to determine if a person is diabetic, vary from morning to afternoon, researchers reported in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
docs.abstract: Study suggests diabetes is more likely to be overlooked in patients given blood tests in afternoon than those tested in morning because plasma glucose levels vary from morning to afternoon; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Many diabetics may be going untreated simply because they were tested for the disease at the wrong time of day.    A recent study suggests that if patients suspected of having diabetes are given blood tests in the afternoon, instead of the morning,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Infection is a major cause of illness and death in newborns, especially among babies who are premature. For doctors combating it, time is of the essence. Now researchers say they have found a new technique that may act as an early warning for infection. Writing in the journal Pediatrics, the researchers, from the University of Virginia Health System, say slight changes in a baby's heart rhythm may signal that there is a problem.

headline.main: Early Warnings That Save Infants' Lives

docs.abstract: University of Virginia Health System researchers say slight changes in heart rhythm may serve as early warning for infection in newborn babies; finding may be especially helpful in treating very premature babies (S)
docs.snippet: Infection is a major cause of illness and death in newborns, especially among babies who are premature. For doctors combating it, time is of the essence.    Now researchers say they have found a new technique that may act as an early warning for...

docs.lead_paragraph: Choice is good. And the more choices, the better. This simple American credo lines the shelves of grocery stores with 162 varieties of breakfast cereal, turns ordering a cup of coffee at Starbucks into an Olympic challenge, makes selecting a phone company an enterprise requiring a business degree and supplies dating services with an endless stream of hopeful customers.

headline.main: In Weird Math of Choices, 6 Choices Can Beat 600

docs.abstract: Studies by social psychologists Drs Sheena S Iyengar and Mark R Lepper find multiplying number of alternatives people are given can become counterproductive; find providing too many options, particularly when differences between them are small, can make people feel overwhelmed and overloaded and thus less likely to buy or pursue any of options; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: American women understandably fear dying from breast cancer, given the numbers who will contract the disease at some point. Breast cancer can be a devastating illness, striking women with no apparent risk factors, often in the prime of life. Many will be subjected to disfiguring surgery, long-term chemotherapy and perhaps weeks of radiation treatment. Their physical scars often pale in comparison with damage to self-image and sexuality, coupled with fear of recurrence or a painful death.

headline.main: Fearing One Fate, Women Ignore a Killer

docs.abstract: Dr Benjamin J Ansell article notes coronary heart disease is leading killer of American women; discusses why women fear breast cancer as killer much more than they do far more deadly heart disease; notes disparity of attention toward women's risk of heart disease extends to health care system; graph comparing heart disease and breast cancer mortality (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Common sense is often the first casualty of a snowstorm. No one knows this better than orthopedic surgeons, who see what happens when people go out to remove snow without taking basic precautions. So, with long-range forecasts predicting heavier-than-usual snowfall this winter, and some parts of the nation still digging out from the heavy storm around New Year's, the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons has issued some advice to help people avoid everything from fractured bones to back injuries, to say nothing of heart attacks.
docs.abstract: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons issues advice to help people avoid snow-shoveling injuries; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Common sense is often the first casualty of a snowstorm. No one knows this better than orthopedic surgeons, who see what happens when people go out to remove snow without taking basic precautions.    So, with long-range forecasts predicting...

docs.lead_paragraph: Children who suffer from migraine headaches can experience relief if they are taught relaxation methods through biofeedback, researchers have found. Writing in the current Neurology, researchers at the Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center said the study suggested that biofeedback training should be incorporated along with medication into the usual treatment for children with migraines.
docs.abstract: Researchers find children who suffer from migraine headaches can be helped if they are taught relaxation methods through biofeedback (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Roto-Rooter operator collapses and dies while working on a drain. Assumption: a heart attack. A seemingly healthy baby dies in his sleep. Assumption: sudden infant death syndrome. An elderly Kentucky woman known from C.T. scans to have malignant-looking lesions in her brain dies before undergoing exploratory surgery. Assumption: metastatic cancer. A 43-year-old Connecticut man with shortness of breath, a cough, positive skin test for tuberculosis and multiple clots in his lungs dies before a biopsy can be performed. Assumption: tuberculosis. But when autopsies were performed on these people, quite different stories emerged. The Roto-Rooter operator was electrocuted, a finding that may have saved the lives of others using the faulty equipment and that resulted in double-indemnity insurance for his survivors.

headline.main: A Price to Pay as Autopsies Lose Favor

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column cites role of autopsy in helping living learn from dead; notes rate of autopsies in nation's hospitals has been falling for decades, largely because of financial pressures; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Much of the past year, I have felt like a foreign correspondent in the land of the old, in the nursing home and assisted living and hospital rooms most of us omit from our travels for as long as we can. As a boomer, my assignment came by virtue of birthright and timing as well as choice. Two months ago, it ended when my 85-year-old father died. Congressional investigators recently issued a report finding widespread violations of federal health and safety standards in nursing homes in five states. To those who live inside many such places, it comes as no surprise. When aged people are dying it is not always ''Tuesdays With Morrie,'' nor does it always involve the exceptional care Bill Moyers portrayed in his PBS series about death.

headline.main: Life's End: Little Help, No Dignity

docs.abstract: Gayle Feldman article on short-staffing that plagues assisted living facilities, including one where her father spent his last months, and out-patient hospice care for terminally ill (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Could there be an end in sight to the yips? Those who don't know the difference between a birdie and a bogey may well think that the reference is to some overlooked Dr. Seuss characters. But, in fact, the yips afflicts regular golfers and is characterized by tremors, jerking or freezing while putting.

headline.main: Keeping the Yips Off the Golf Greens

docs.abstract: Mayo Clinic researchers say yips, tremors, jerking or freezing that afflict many regular golfers while putting may have both physical and psychological roots; photo (M)
